Liz, how did you first get involved with the Cardiff Carnival?
I got involved with Swicker because I volunteered for them.
So I was studying graphic design in Cardiff and I'd just come to the end of my course,
graduated and had a minor, oh my God, what am I going to do moment.

So I volunteered over three weeks, three weekends doing that, enjoyed it, had a great time.

you guys got in touch with me and asked if I'd like to work as a trainee.

Yes. Tell us a bit about your freelance artistic practice.
OK, so I'm a graphic designer and an illustrator.
I kind of straddle the two. So I'm not quite one and not quite the other and a bit of both really.
So, yeah, visual communication, really.
So I do some bits of graphic design work like logos, brochures and stuff for web.
But then I also do some illustration work for people when they need it.
But also I teach. So I'm a lecturer up in Hereford College of Arts and I do bits and pieces in Cardiff as well.
So I'm a bit of a jigsaw of different bits and pieces, really.
But having done the proper job for a few years, I just got to the point where I was like, oh, you know what, this isn't me.
All I was doing was managing other people and not really getting to even teach.
I was very much in a in a in a middle management role.
And although that was challenging in its own way, I wasn't getting the contact with people or the chance to to really be creative myself.
So I just got to the point where I thought, you know what, I've just got to take the plunge and see what happens.
If it doesn't turn into anything, then I can get another job.
But it did. So it's all good and I'm happy.
